source_methodology: Evidence-based guidelines from top sports science and training textbooks
research_quality: Meta-analyses, systematic reviews, and peer-reviewed studies

source_books: Science and Practice of Strength Training (3rd Ed.)
NSCA's Essentials of Strength Training (4th Ed.)
guidelines.scientific_definition: Maximal strength is the highest force that can be generated by the neuromuscular system during a single voluntary contraction
guidelines.research_foundation: Meta-analysis of 140+ studies demonstrates optimal parameters for strength development

primary_exercises.rationale: Highest loading potential for lower body, 15-20% transfer to athletic performance
primary_exercises.research: Wisloff et al. (2004): Half squat strength correlates with sprint and jump performance

primary_exercises.rationale: Highest absolute loading exercise, develops total body strength coordination
primary_exercises.research: Swinton et al. (2011): Comprehensive analysis of deadlift biomechanics

primary_exercises.rationale: Primary upper body strength measure, high neural activation
primary_exercises.research: Saeterbakken & Fimland (2013): Muscle activity and strength development

guidelines.exercise_order: 1. Highest neural demand exercises first, 2. Large muscle groups before small, 3. Multi-joint before single-joint

volume_guidelines.research: Schoenfeld et al. (2017): Dose-response relationship for strength training volume

periodization_model.type: Linear periodization most effective for strength gains
periodization_model.research: Rhea et al. (2004): Meta-analysis demonstrates 23.5% greater strength gains with periodization

adaptation_timeline.research: Folland & Williams (2007): Mechanisms of strength development

source_books: Science and Practice of Strength Training
guidelines.scientific_definition: Hypertrophy is the increase in muscle fiber size through increased protein synthesis and satellite cell incorporation
guidelines.research_foundation: Meta-analysis of 200+ studies on hypertrophy training parameters

primary_exercises.rationale: Superior upper chest development vs flat bench, 30% greater upper pec activation
primary_exercises.research: Barnett et al. (1995): EMG analysis of chest exercises

primary_exercises.rationale: Comprehensive back development, highest lat and rhomboid activation
primary_exercises.research: Lehman et al. (2004): Comparison of rowing exercise variations

primary_exercises.rationale: Unilateral leg development prevents asymmetries, high glute activation
primary_exercises.research: Boudreau et al. (2009): Lunge variations and muscle activation

volume_requirements.research: Schoenfeld et al. (2017): Volume landmarks for muscle hypertrophy
volume_requirements.progression: Add 1-2 sets every 2 weeks until maximum tolerable volume

primary_rep_ranges.6-12_reps: 60% of total volume - optimal hypertrophy stimulus
primary_rep_ranges.12-20_reps: 25% of total volume - metabolic stress emphasis
primary_rep_ranges.3-6_reps: 15% of total volume - mechanical tension emphasis

training_frequency.optimal: Each muscle group 2x per week minimum
training_frequency.rationale: Protein synthesis elevated for 48-72 hours post-exercise
training_frequency.research: Schoenfeld et al. (2016): Training frequency and hypertrophy

guidelines.scientific_definition: Power is the rate of doing work (P = F × V), crucial for athletic performance requiring rapid force development
guidelines.research_foundation: 40+ years of research on power development from Soviet sport science

primary_exercises.rationale: Develops rate of force development, 18% improvement in vertical jump
primary_exercises.research: Comfort et al. (2012): Power clean vs jump training for power development

primary_exercises.rationale: Exploits stretch-shortening cycle, superior to weight training for jump performance
Develops concentric power without eccentric braking, sport-specific velocities
primary_exercises.research: Stockbrugger & Haennel (2003): Medicine ball training effects

strength_foundation.focus: Develop force capacity (F in P=F×V equation)

force_velocity_curve_targeting.research: Cormie et al. (2011): Optimal loading for power development

guidelines.scientific_definition: Movement quality refers to the ability to perform movement patterns efficiently without compensation or dysfunction

functional_movement_screen.research: Kiesel et al. (2007): FMS predicts injury in professional football players

movement_competency.criteria: Pain-free, full range of motion, no compensation patterns

primary_interventions.purpose: Identifies mobility and stability limitations throughout kinetic chain

programming.assessment: 3 reps from anterior, lateral, posterior views

common_dysfunctions: Arms fall forward: Thoracic spine extension limitation
Knees cave in: Hip stability deficit

primary_interventions.purpose: Addresses most common restrictions: hip flexors, thoracic spine, shoulders

programming.progression: Add thoracic rotation or overhead reach

injury_prevention_outcomes.movement_screening: 65% reduction in injury risk when dysfunctions addressed
injury_prevention_outcomes.mobility_programs: 40% reduction in overuse injuries in athletes
injury_prevention_outcomes.research: Kiesel et al. (2007, 2014): Movement screening and injury prediction

return_to_activity_standards.movement_competency: Score >14 on FMS before sport participation
return_to_activity_standards.asymmetry_limits: <10% difference between limbs in strength/mobility tests
return_to_activity_standards.pain_free_movement: No pain during functional movement patterns
return_to_activity_standards.research: Cook et al. (2014): Movement standards for injury prevention
